title: In The Count of Monte Cristo, Dumas off-handedly refers to Italian cookery as 'the worst in the world'. How prevalent was this view at the time, and when did it change? - Quora
tags: The Count of Monte Cristo (2002 movie)
The Count of Monte Cristo (1844-45 book)

response.answer_text: I don't really know. But I do know that he was well known as a gourmet and wrote several treatises on cooking, so he probably knew what he was talking about. Still it seems a pretty broad statement. I personally love Italian cookery, but then again having never been to Italy, it could be the Americanized version of Italian cooking I like. I have heard that pizzas here are very different from those made in Italy. The Italian pizzas are supposed to be more bland and don't have the variety of toppings we have. Then different regions of Italy have different styles of cooking, so he may have been talking about a particular region of Italy.

I don’t think I can answer this question, as cookery is not an area I know a great deal about, apart from vegetarian and vegan dishes (I am vegetarian) and Greek food (We are Greek in my family). Perhaps Dumas, like most Frenchmen, considered anything other than French cuisine to be inferior (?) Could anyone else answer the question?
